choices.A: STP BPDUs that are generated by Switch2 are received by Switch1 and Switch3.
choices.C: Cisco ACI acts as the STP root for all three external switches.
choices.B: Cisco ACI fabric drops all STP BPDUs that are generated by the external switches.
choices.D: STP BPDUs that are generated by Switch1 are received only by Switch3.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The same VLAN on different VLAN pools and different domains will result in different FD VLANs and, therefore, different FD VNIDs.

Selected Answer: D
D. STP BPDUs that are generated by Switch1 are received only by Switch3.

comments.content: Ofc but they ask how aci forward it

discussion.content: A, switches 1 and 3 are directly connected to 2

I cam across this:
https://aci-troubleshooting-lab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/epg.html

"ACI floods STP Bridge Protocol Data Units (BPDUs) to the VXLAN network identifier (VNID) assigned to the FD VLAN. VNID is assigned through the VLAN pool so encapsulation has to be part of same VLAN pool to be in part of same STP domain."

So D seems indeed correct!

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. How are the STP BPDUs forwarded over Cisco ACI fabric?

choices.D: Enable Limit IP Learning to Subnet

discussion.content:
Option B is correct, because Limit IP Learning to Subnet doesn't work with remote endpoints.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/data-center-virtualization/application-centric-infrastructure/white-paper-c11-739989.html

Selected Answer: B
B. Enable Enforce Subnet Check

comments.content: Limit IP Learning to Subnet is only for local endpoints whereas Enforce Subnet Check is applied to both local and remote endpoints.

questions.question_text: An engineer must limit local and remote endpoint learning to the bridge domain subnet. Which action should be taken inside the Cisco APIC?

choices.E: The PVST simulation must be configured on external network switches to support MSTP.
choices.D: A dedicated EPG must be created for the native VLAN ID with static bindings toward the MSTP-enabled switches.
choices.C: Mis-cabling protocol is used to snoop the MSTP TCN packets.
choices.B: A static path binding is required for native VLAN to carry the MST BPDUs in existing EPGs.
choices.A: A Cisco ACI leaf flushes all local endpoints in the received EPG when an MSTP TCN frame is received.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
A and D most sense to me

comments.content: Correct, the question ask for MST

questions.question_text: What are two characteristics of Cisco ACI interaction with MSTP? (Choose two.)
What is a design implication for Cisco ACI using an application-centric approach?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
This design implication means that within a single bridge domain, you can have multiple End Point Groups (EPGs) and multiple VLANs. This approach allows for greater flexibility and more granular segmentation of traffic within the network, aligning with the application-centric model of Cisco ACI.

choices.D: One VLAN equals one EPG equals one bridge domain
choices.C: One EPG is mapped to multiple bridge domains
choices.B: VLAN numbers are in the names of the bridge domain and EPG objects
choices.A: Multiple VLANs and/or multiple EPGs are under one bridge domain

questions.question_text: What are two characteristics of network-centric design in Cisco ACI? (Choose two.)

choices.E: A bridge domain has one subnet and one EPG
choices.A: There is open communication between EPGs

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
EPGs are security zones for application-centric design. The network-centric design is more similar to what we have in non-ACI networks. No security rules at the beginning and EPGs are to group servers in VLANs. After the migration is completed, we start to create contracts etc.

Selected Answer: CE
I think C E makes more sense, EPG as a separate security zone, EPG to EPG requires contract to enable communication/traffic, as for B. microsegmentation this doesnt necessarily correspond to this question, also microsegmentation makes more sense for application centric approach
